Origins: The creature pictured above is the Theridion grallator , more commonly known as the "happy face spider." The colorful arachnid is native to four of the Hawaiian islands (Oahu, Molokai, Maui, Hawaii), where it is known in the local language as nananana makaki'i, or the "face-patterned spider." (The word grallator in its specific name is Latin for "stilt walker," a reference to the spider's long and spindly legs.)
Description: Although some Theridion grallator do bear markings resembling a happy face or a smiling clown on their abdomens as seen in the image shown above, the average person is unlikely to observe such markings without deliberately setting out to do so: The happy face spider is very small (about 1/5 of an inch long) and typically hides under forest leaves during the day, so one would generally have to search carefully to find an example and then examine it under a magnifying glass to glimpse a real-life example of the "happy face" markings.
